summary: This document is a lengthy email from whistleblower Christopher Dilorio to the SEC Office of the Whistleblower, appealing the denial of his award claim for the Oppenheimer AML covered action (2015-016). He alleges the SEC used his information to both bring and obstruct complaints, specifically protecting entities like Knight Capital (NITE) and UBS (UBSS) while denying him compensation. He details a complex web of alleged money laundering through penny stock shells, naked shorting, and SEC obstruction.

persons.name: Christopher Dilorio
persons.context: Author of the email and primary whistleblower alleging massive securities fraud, money laundering, and SEC obstruction related to Knight Capital, UBS, and various penny stock shells.

persons.name: Justin W. Keener
persons.context: Operated JMJ Financial; charged by SEC in 2020 for unregistered penny stock dealing; linked by Dilorio to money laundering shells like IMDS and CGFIA.

persons.name: Joshua Sason
persons.context: Charged by SEC in 2019 for roles in microcap frauds and unlawful offerings; linked by Dilorio to Hanover/Magna and money laundering shells like NewLead.

persons.name: Michael Farkas
persons.context: Previously involved with Skyway Communications, whose registration was revoked by SEC in 2007; mentioned in context of money laundering shells.

persons.name: Jonathan New
persons.context: Formerly CFO of AQR/Crede; linked by Dilorio to Milken-related money laundering.

persons.name: Donald Engel
persons.context: Worked at Drexel with Michael Milken; mentioned in context of money laundering networks.

persons.name: Gregg Jaclin
persons.context: Shell factory attorney barred as SEC lawyer; linked to Honig, Stetson, Alpha Capital.

persons.name: Brian Colleran
persons.context: Linked to Trump Cleveland fundraiser and Millennium Bio/Inergetics shell.

persons.name: Jane Norberg
persons.context: Recipient of Dilorio's appeal; former assistant to Sean McKessy; accused of mishandling whistleblower information.

persons.name: Sean McKessy
persons.context: Former head of SEC Office of the Whistleblower; solicited more information from Dilorio after receiving his TCR.

persons.name: Robin Traxler
persons.context: FINRA official with whom Dilorio corresponded extensively in 2012 about penny stock shells CGFIA and AppTech.

persons.name: Dan Coleman
persons.context: Became CEO of KCG after reverse merger; previously ran Equities at UBS during Reg SHO violations; central to Dilorio's allegations of SEC protection.

persons.name: Oleg Firer
persons.context: Grenada Ambassador to Russia living in Miami; involved with Net Element, which Dilorio alleges is a money laundering shell.

persons.name: Terren Peizer
persons.context: Linked to Crede and Net Element; associated with felon partner Michael Wachs.

persons.name: Michael Wachs
persons.context: Felon partner of Terren Peizer; linked to Net Element offerings through ex-wife and sister's entities.

persons.name: Martin Schlaff
persons.context: Austria/Israel based; controls Alpha Capital Anstalt; linked to Frost/Honig/Stetson complaint and IMDS.

persons.name: Jay Clayton
persons.context: Accused by Dilorio of undisclosed conflicts via his firm Sullivan Cromwell and Jared Fishman, who advised Knight/KCG/VIRT.

persons.name: Jared Fishman
persons.context: Advised Knight/KCG/VIRT transactions; linked to SEC Chair Clayton; accused of facilitating fraud.

persons.name: Carl Hoecker
persons.context: Accused by Dilorio of criminal obstruction for not interviewing him, not informing Congress, and conducting inadequate investigations.

persons.name: David Della Sciucca, Jr.
persons.context: Resident of Fort Lauderdale; charged by SEC in Gibraltar Global Securities complaint related to Magnum d'Or shell.

persons.name: David Urban
persons.context: Trump PA Campaign Manager; sits on the board of Knight Capital (NITE) and his own alleged money laundering shell FSD Parma.

persons.name: John McCarthy
persons.context: Formerly at SEC NY; ended up as Chief Counsel at Knight/KCG; linked by Dilorio to Madoff investigation failures.

persons.name: Cromwell Coulson
persons.context: Chaired the FINRA Market Regulation Committee; Dilorio implies OTC Markets exists for abusive naked shorting and money laundering.

persons.name: Andrew Wimpfheimer
persons.context: Founding OTC Markets Board member; former NITE trader.

persons.name: Vikas Arora
persons.context: IRS Criminal Investigation agent who flew to Denver to meet with Dilorio in April 2016 about his TCR.

persons.name: Nathan Sarnacki
persons.context: IRS Criminal Investigation agent who flew to Denver with Vikas Arora to meet with Dilorio.

persons.name: Marc P. Berger
persons.context: SEC official named in the Sason/Magna/NewLead complaint; Dilorio previously worked with Berger Montague law firm.

connections.description: Dilorio is appealing the denial of his whistleblower award to SEC OWB Chief Norberg, accusing the SEC of using his information unethically.
Dilorio corresponded with former OWB Chief McKessy, who solicited more information from him after receiving his TCR.
Dilorio alleges NITE was the executing broker/dealer for Keener/JMJ's money laundering penny stock shells, converting worthless certs into real money.
Sason is linked to Hanover/Magna entities in microcap frauds and money laundering schemes involving shells like NewLead and CGFIA.
Dilorio alleges NITE and UBSS traded billions of shares of the same OTCM money laundering shells (CGFIA, IMDS, APCX) in a coordinated, illegal naked shorting scheme.
Coleman ran Equities at UBS during its Reg SHO and cross-border AML violations before becoming CEO of KCG.
Both worked at law firm Sullivan Cromwell, which advised Knight/KCG/VIRT on transactions Dilorio alleges were fraudulent.
Engel worked at Drexel with Milken; Dilorio links Milken network to various money laundering shells and entities.
Schlaff controls Liechtenstein-based Alpha Capital Anstalt, involved in money laundering shells like IMDS and linked to Frost/Honig.

events.title: Dilorio's First Whistleblower Complaint
events.description: Christopher Dilorio filed his first whistleblower complaint with the SEC, detailing massive fraud centered on Knight Capital (NITE) and UBS (UBSS).

events.title: Knight Capital "Glitch"
events.description: Knight Capital suffered a massive trading loss due to a software glitch, leading to an emergency bailout. Dilorio claims this proved his prior allegations of insolvency and involved Knight inadvertently sending 4000 worthless securities to JPMorgan as collateral.

events.title: Dilorio's Amended TCR Filed with Berger
events.description: Dilorio submitted his amended Tip, Complaint or Referral (TCR) with Berger Montague to the SEC, detailing illegal activity at Knight Capital and UBS.

events.title: DTCC Global Lock on CGFIA
events.description: The Depository Trust & Clearing Corporation (DTCC) imposed a 'Global Lock' on Colorado Goldfields (CGFIA) stock due to actions by a third-party broker-dealer, which Dilorio cites as clear evidence of naked shorting.

events.title: SEC Oppenheimer AML Action
events.description: The SEC brought an administrative proceeding against Oppenheimer & Co. for anti-money laundering failures, which Dilorio claims was based on his information and the FINRA complaint.

events.title: VIRT Acquisition of KCG
events.description: Virtu Financial (VIRT) acquired KCG. Dilorio alleges the transaction was fraudulent, with VIRT CEO Cifu refusing to publish KCG's Q2 2017 financials and writing down over $4 billion in open naked short fails.

events.title: SEC Charges Against Joshua Sason et al.
events.description: The SEC charged Joshua Sason and others for roles in microcap frauds and unlawful offerings, which Dilorio claims was based on his separate TCRs filed years prior.

events.title: SEC Charges Justin Keener/JMJ Financial
events.description: The SEC charged Justin W. Keener d/b/a JMJ Financial as an unregistered penny stock dealer. Dilorio claims he informed the SEC about Keener seven years earlier.

events.title: Dilorio's Formal Appeal to SEC OWB
events.description: Christopher Dilorio sends this formal appeal of the SEC's preliminary denial of his award claim for the Oppenheimer AML covered action (2015-016), alleging extensive SEC obstruction and misuse of his information.

locations: Santa Monica, CA (HQ of New Concepts)
Denver, CO / Littleton, CO (Related to CGFIA CEO Guyer)
The Woodlands, TX and Boca Raton, FL (AppTech offices)
Miami, FL (Residence of Oleg Firer, Justin Keener)
Fort Lauderdale, FL (Residence of David Della Sciucca, Jr.)
keyFacts: The whistleblower, Christopher Dilorio, alleges the SEC has used his detailed TCR information since 2011 to both bring enforcement actions (e.g., against Oppenheimer, Joshua Sason, Justin Keener) and to obstruct investigations that would implicate major players like Knight Capital (NITE) and UBS (UBSS).

Dilorio's core claim is that Knight Capital (later KCG, now part of Virtu) is a criminal enterprise whose primary business is abusive naked shorting of OTC market shells to facilitate money laundering, and that the SEC has actively protected it since bailing it out after the 2012 'glitch'.

The document points to a DTCC 'Global Lock' on Colorado Goldfields (CGFIA) in 2013 as 'smoking gun' evidence of naked shorting by a third-party broker-dealer, which the SEC allegedly ignored despite having Dilorio's information.

Dilorio accuses the SEC Office of the Whistleblower and Inspector General Carl Hoecker of gross misconduct, including failing to distribute his information to investigators, not interviewing him, and not informing Congress of his serious allegations.

The email outlines a vast network of alleged money laundering involving Michael Milken associates, shell companies (AQR blanks, NewLead, FreeSeas), Swiss banks (UBS), and entities linked to figures like Martin Schlaff, with connections to political figures (Trump, Kushner) and recent CARES Act fund recipients.
